reviewText:
Only buy this game if it's 75 cents or less.

Legendary has it's upsides, the most notable being the premise of the game. Griphons and other mythological creatures invading the modern world is the selling point of this game, and it ends there. Literally everything else about the game is bad or poorly imagined.

First off, this game is broken. Absolutely, fundamentally broken. You literally can not beat this game if you just install it and play it. Right before the final level, there is a game-breaking glitch that causes you to fall through the floor. It is impossible to complete the game. There are a few files you can change to fix this, but the fact that this is included in the game shows how little the developers care, and how poorly the game was ported to PC.

The gameplay is boring and repetative. There are about 3 enemy types you will regularly be fighting throughout the game, most of which are just cannon fodder. A plus gameplay wise is that you get health by absorbing enemy souls, and I find this to be the only redeeming quality of this game in a world of regenerating health shooters.

The environments and character design are actually pretty decent. AI teammates will occasionally warp through walls, and you can stand inside of them as well. Friendly character clipping wasn't taken into account at all. The animations for most characters are done nicely, but some enemies have poor animation cycles when waiting for a cutscene event.

Cutscenes in this game aren't impressive in the slightest. Every time you beat a major story plot point, you are given a slideshow of images and text that is read aloud. The most dissapointing part of the game is at the very end. After you fix the glitch and get to the final level, you complete 3 simple tasks and are given a wall of text. I have never been so dissapointed with an ending since watching Evangelion.

My final verdict is to get it on sale. As a game, it isn't so bad that it should be avoided, but you should definitely not pay full price for it. This game is common in indie bundles and I've seen it go as low as $0.74 (Â£0.59) on Steam.

reviewText:
So if you haven't noticed yet, this game doesn't get the best reviews, but this is more of a neutral review. Since steam doesn't give me a neutral option I will put to not recommend. My reasoning behind this is because for the most part the game has a lot of technical problems and one huge game breaking bug that happened in an elevator that leads to the final battle of the game, with all these issues I can't bring myself to recommend this even if I enjoyed it. One issue I had was the controls, the way your character moves is very stiff, he jumps like 2 inches off the ground which is annoying when there are some vital points in the game where you need the ability to jump a little, but when you sprint he's all over the place. Another technical issue is the shooting, they have a weird delay from when you shoot the gun to when its supposed to register on the enemy, this makes shooting moving targets more difficult, but it seems to only occur when you shoot human enemies. There are a few more but those are the most important ones to know about, the big elevator glitch I pointed out earlier (which would drop me through the floor of the elevator when it started to move ending up in me falling forever or being stuck below the level) took me a while to find a fix for, some people said to mess around in the ini files, some people said to look at an angle, some said to use FRAPS to limit the fps of the game, so what fixed it was a combo of everything. Multiplayer for me at least was out of the question based the problems with the single player and the fact that you didn't a different account just to play it.

But not all is bad with this game, I like the story of fighting a bunch of mythical creatures who were let out because the character you play as was hired/tricked to open Pandora's Box, and the whole game nobody really busts his balls over it, they just accept that he did it and tries to fix it. The creatures are amazing, each one brings their own challanges, Minotaurs are fast, strong, and take awhile to kill while Nari's are more stealthy, come in packs, and are invicible untill they get ready to attack. I was surprised by some of the great face animations from the characters while in game (not cutscenes) reminded me a lot of BioShock Infinite. Some people complain about the graphics but to me they were pretty good especially for the time this came out. The game was very action packed, you are constantly going against something that surprises you and keeps you on your toes, watching massives golems destory the city while griffons fly over head is just one of the wonderful sights of the environment around you will your fighting. I do wish there were more enemies just to bring more diversity and a longer single player experience.

This is a decent game that I feel is haunted by a lot of technical issues, I would recommend it with a warning but in this case I don't think most people would enjoy this as much as me, but if you can get it for cheap you have nothing to lose, give it a shot.

reviewText:
Legendary is a horror action first person shooter in the fashion of Duke Nukem Forever and Half-Life 2. Horror as in blood and gory, but not scary, its action first. You have unlocked Pandora's Box, and you'll have to fight mythological creatures to present day New York City and London. You'll fight flying griffins, charging minotaurs, sneaky werewolves, and yes someone released the Kraken. The thing that stands out about the game are the fights. Not just you fighting the enemies, but your allies fighting a hostile faction and enemies attacking everything living. It all adds to a level of strategy. Do you shoot open the lock to a werewolf's cage and have it attack your enemies? Do you flank your enemies while your allies keep them occupied or throw a grenade? One enemy can attack another and light it on fire. Combat isn't scripted. Your allies will die and that's okay. You can leave them, you're not chained to them, but they do help you.

The game has brief cut scenes, THAT ARE NOT SKIPABLE. Some of the cut scenes are like an advanced slide show with beautiful art and voice overs. I'd rather see that when interluding between things. There is humor here and there. About once every two hours without being in your face. The game will tell you where to go, what to do with voice overs, because that's what first person shooters do. Thankfully this one says use the rocket launcher against that griffin instead of hold that button, to lock on the griffin, then press that button to fire the rocket. So it keeps me in game. What doesn't keep me in game is the loading screen when I died. I died a lot on medium difficulty when it came to the bosses. I'd say more than other similar first person shooters. There is no easy health. No health kits, no regenerating health at least on medium difficulty. Things will crush you, such as the Kraken's giant purple tentacles. You need to stay sharp and look up.

When you start the game, you're given incredible hand powers to do three things. You can absorb what I'll call souls" from dead creatures. Absorbing souls takes time and you need to hold down the button
date: but if there are 3 souls in 1 area it only needs to be done once to absorb all souls. With these souls you can either hold the same hand button to heal yourself or double press it to send out a wave that stuns enemies. Other than that the weapons are pretty basic
recommended: you have a pistol (which I never used)

reviewText:
I don't understand why this game's got such a bad rating. It's very old school similar to Doom, it's linear and you shoot everything that moves. The monsters are cool and the minotaurs can be hard to kill sometimes. I did not encounter any bugs except one, which I agree is game breaking. I took forumer ZanyCynic's advice below and was able to progress without any issues.

To fix the Elevator bug, Open the PandoraEngine.ini (on vista it is on C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\My Games\Legendary\PandoraGame\Config-Folder) and search for
MaxSmoothedFrameRate=300" and change the value to 30. So the game runs at maximum 30 fps. Play through to next check point save then edit it back to 300 and continue game.

I got this for 99 cents and it's well worth it if you pick it up during a sale. I defnitely recommend playing it if you like old school games like Doom

reviewText:
This game is better than most people say it is. I think it's a good thing this game got so much bad press, because you will go into it expecting crap, and you will be surprised by how not crap it is. Actually, you'll probably be amazed at all the scripted events and chaos and enemies lurking about. A griffon causing havoc, breaking into buildings and nearly taking your head off, another griffon flying through a cathedral... truly... this is some fantastic stuff for a game released in 2008. And it looks good too.

Also, Legendary touches upon a story that, when you see Pandora's Box as a symbol for genetic splicing, is all too realistic and believable. I think this scares the haters and they don't want to admit it, so while in fear they just hate.

For FPS games, this is pretty good. Granted, it's not the most engaging, but if you play the game with the mind that that awesome fireman's axe is your primary weapon and what you use for most of the game, believe me, this game all of a sudden becomes very engaging and worthwhile. The guns are pretty good, but there's something lacking in engaging enemies with them, but that axe... it's all about that axe and hunting werewolves with it. A good challenge is to face the first Minotaur with the axe. Grenades and molotovs are very welcome to use, but always weild that axe.

The enemies, not including the humans, are also really well done. The Nari are very well scripted and a real treat to witness and axe to death. They go around lifting things and throwing them at you. They appear in front of your face and do a little mockery dance. They lift soda machines and cause the soda cans to fly out at you. The Nari truly make this game really enjoyable. Of course, they are an enemy, but a very unique enemy. It's obvious a lot of love went into creating them.

Also, there's that game-breaking bug at the end, which solutions have been made available by players.

If this game ever got achievements, it would only need one. I challenge all you players to earn it:


Legendary - Beat the game weilding the fireman's axe for at least 80% of the game


This is how you make a decent game more fun. Enjoy.

reviewText:
An interesting game with some amazing visuals.  For once we get a fresh take on battling monsters, instead of taking place in the far flung fantasy filled past of wizards or knights, or in a galaxy far far away in some doom wannabe, we get a game that lets us take on mythological creatures of the past in the modern world.  This game does have bugs, its not perfect, and the controls are kind of shot.  Some strange bugs encountered was that the sun in the sky would appear through objects or when in an enclosed room or tunnel and one gamebreaking bug at the end of the game.  The game played with a keyboard and mouse is way to easy.   The controller controls arent great they skate around and the look or aim seems to often fly all over.  While normally I would hate that, this isnt a platformer where any precise jumps are required.  In a way the bad controls added to the challenge.  Somehow the floaty controls for aiming made me feel like I was there since noone would stay perfect in that situation with their aim.

Multiplayer is dead since gamespy is dead, but the story is fun, many of the visuals of the blown up burned out city are great.  Def worth a playthrough and if its too easy  just exit and change the difficulty.

To pass the elevator glitch that kills you at the end of the game go to C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\My Games\Legendary\PandoraGame\Config" set framerate to 30
date: then play until the next checkpoint exit and set it back to 300.\n\nRating:  5/10  Value:  $4.99"

reviewText:
Here's a game with an interesting premise that falls flat.

Gunplay is wonky, ADS is hard to control (and seems pointless anyway).

Combat is, well, boring.

Enemies have rudimentary AI that's easy to overcome. Human enemies tend to stick behind cover with their heads sticking out and stationary, making them easy one-shot kills.

The constant werewolves are easy to take out with automatic fire, and if you have trouble with a minotaur, use a flamethrower.

Ammunition is more than abundant, meaning that, even if you didn't have super-human accuracy, you'd still not run out.

Constant hold button to open door" prompts severely interrupt the flow of gameplay and probably are a result of consolitis
date: the press-and-hold prompts being a way to allow consoles to catchup on load times.\n\nMultiplayer is Gamespy-reliant
hoursPlayed: there's a bug in the last elevator that causes you to fall through the floor
voteText: either killing you or leaving you falling forever.\n\nSince the devs won't fix it (claim they can't fix it)

here's a solution I had to find.

Open PandoraInput.ini
Change Bindings=(Name=â€PageDownâ€
votesHelpful: Command=â€dummyâ€) to Bindings=(Name=â€PageDownâ€
votesTotal: Command=â€walkâ€œ)\nChange Bindings=(Name=â€PageUpâ€
commentsCount: Command=â€ghostâ€œ)\n\nWhen you fall through the floor of the elevator
column16: hit PageUp to go into noclip (ghost) mode
column17:
then follow the elevator. Get out of noclip mode when you catch up with it (PageDown).

What should have been an amazing game with an excellent premise turned out to be about seven hours of just "meh" gameplay with an ending that has no resolution and promises a sequel we'll probably never see.

If you see it for 50 cents

reviewText:
I wish Steam had a neutral button.

The Story, random guy has to steal the box of pandora but opened it by curiosity (or had to open it, idk it doesnt change anything) -> legendary creatures invade the capitals of some countrys -> you need to save it
Is quite generic but also thanks to the creatures such as gryphons, minotaurs and werewolfs it had potential.

Pro:
- Recource System.  Once you killed a creature of the pandora you get energy that can be used as a knockback skill or selfheal.
- The groundskeeper tbat randomly cleaned the military base in the middle of the game although the whole world is about to collaps (he sure likes his job, i enjoyed watching him ^-^... the fact that he is in the pro says pretty much all about the rest.. doesnt it?)
- Atmosphere of the surface (shame you get to play mostly in subway stations and others so you cant see the scenery that much... destroying world seems to be nice)
- The cracen as Boss was quite spectacular... RELEASE THE CRACEN!  (although he was not realy hard...)
- The first time you get to face Minotaur and Gryphon as a enemy (miniboss), the feeling of the fight actually is pretty nice. After the first one you simply nuke them with rocket launcher or getlingun and that makes it quite dull again.

Cons:
- The last lvl has a BUGG where you have to change the maxframerate to 30 or you will get bugged in the elevator
- too less monsters (you mostly fight against werewolfs... which first seem to be a nice enemy as you have to execute them, but you will soon notice that you do not need to lasthit him with a meleweapon but still simply shoot him... lame)
- You actually fight more military men than monsters
- The synchro is not that good (some maybe will think otherwise)
- Whole game is based on checkpoint data which means that nothing is random in the world but actually spawns for you at the right moment... the checkpoint part also occurs for the military guys you get as support... they die about 1 or 2 minutes after you get them by default (mostly even secounds after you get them).... all... the....time..... that gets boring
- The scoped version of the weapons is too fast and it is actually therefore easier to aim without scoping at all... (if you are playing ego shooters all the time you might think not so, but at the moment i do not play shooter games that much)
- You can barely get out of ammo and therefore the melee weapon is just a style way to killl (most weapon spots have unlimited amount of resupply)
- The mobs randomly spawn and sometimes they don't see you at all although you are right in front of them
- 3-5 hours of gameplay for 7gb to download is not realy efficient.
- Decard can actually jump like 5-10 centimeters high... that is so unrealistic and makes it quite clear where you have to go..
- The whole world arround you dies, you actually have nothing to fear at all as you are never in a realy huge threat... lame
...
- probably some points i have forgotten

Result:
This game is not realy worth to play, BUT when you see it for its saleprice of not even 1â‚¬ (0,95 or sth like that) you can pick it up.. this game is so terrible in many stages that it is actually fun to play because it is so bad.
It is worth the 1â‚¬ but not the 5â‚¬ it is sold

Probably a 3-4 / 10

It had potential to be a good game but the potential was not used correctly so it became a quite bad but still playable (no replay value at all) game

reviewText:
It's decent

Pro's:
Enemy's are interesting

Mid:
Story, narration, and delivery is awkward but cheesy

Con's:
Weapon variety
Level Design
Level textures sometimes doesn't load

Details:

The enemy designes aren't per say interesting, it's more of how you deal with them.  Some you can only shoot the head, others only the back, others when their mouth is open, etc.  I wish more games did that with their enemies, and sometimes they will react to getting shot.  The story is... interesting but also stupid, the way it's told is kinda forced and kinda half-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ at the same time, a few conversations are interesting but the story is mostly a few cutscenes and some hidden messages all through out the levels.  There are only around half a dozen weapons through the whole game, and there are clear better weapons. The levels themselves are hit and miss, sometimes you'll be powering up something while a team gets your back, other times your wading through set-peices, and other times you have no idea what the hell you need to do to continue forward.  And sometimes when you play for long periods, the textures in the levels don't load; not just on objects like cars or rocks, but whole water-ways, backgrounds, even enemies.

You get around 6-8 hours of gameplay from this game, and for that price, I think it's worth it if your looking for something to waste 6-8 hours on, you can do a hell of a lot worse.

reviewText:
This game really makes me wish Steam had a neutral option for reviewing games.

In Legendary you play as an art thief who has been tricked in to stealing and opening Pandoraâ€™s Box, subsequently releasing deadly mythological creatures in to the world.

Combat is your basic FPS, although your selection of weapons is pretty limited. Aiming seems to be off center, its not uncommon to have a perfect aim of an enemy and have it tell you that you missed. The monsters are by far the best part of this game. There are a lot of different types to fight, all of which present their own unique challenge.

The movement is rather stiff, but not game breaking. Jumping can be a bit awkward, and random things can get in the way of your walking.

The AI can be a bit off at times, sometimes leaping around in a way that was obviously not intended. Enemies also seem to spawn continuously, sometimes appearing out of thin air, which can be a bit frustrating at times.

You are forced to use checkpoints to save. Some of these checkpoints are awkwardly placed, sometimes forcing you to repeat trivial areas.

Overall, the gameplay is mediocre and buggy, but thanks to awesome monsters and cool visuals it still manages to provide some fun.

NOT worth the full asking price. Pay that amount and you are guaranteed to end up with buyer's remorse. I got it on sale for $0.75, which I think is a better price.

reviewText: The well-known legend of Pandoraâ€™s Box demands much more than what Developer Spark created here. Also, it just doesnâ€™t seem right that Deckard is capable of force pushing and draining life-energy, but utterly fails at simple jumping. The single-player campaign is quite short, but full of spectacular and varied scenes. It's a lot of fun, but too linear, and the use of generic weapons, imprecise controls and inconsistent graphics show a lack of fine-tuning.Legendary isnâ€™t the most involved or technically excellent shooter out there, but itâ€™s a fun change of pace with extremely satisfying combat.

reviewText: Great game in terms of price and what you get with the cheap price. You play as a theif who is hired to steal an ancient artifact...Pandora's Box! Unsuccessfully you have unleashed an ancient mythological evil across the world. It is up to you to right a wrong. Face off against a cult like human organization and greek mythological creatures. Feels like a B action movie in Hollywood. Weapons are fun to use, plot is actually suprisingly interesting that makes you want to keep playing. As it says in the game description, your enemies are your enemies enemies. How is that for a tongue twister lol. Enviroments are destructable in both New York and London settings. Get this game on a discount because at least to me it will feel like an absolute steal. Don't mind the Metascore. It may not be Call of Duty, it is however a worthwhile purchase and is worth your time.

reviewText:
Good day together,

I have seen a lot of reviews with less than 1 hour playtime and I wanted to finish the game at least before I write my opinion here. Sadly  I wasn`t able to finish the game but I will write what I think.

Story (short version..):

You stole Pandoras Box and opended it. Suddenly you got superpowers from opening the box and a lot of monsters got summoned to the earth. Like Drakes, Griffins, Ghosts, Werwolfes and stuff... A bad guy wants to controll them and you are the only one who can stop him.

Gameplay:

The graphics are ok......For a 2008 game at least. You can sprint 10 metres than your character is breathing like he is going to die. The jump is sometimes completly broken, you cant jump over 20cm obstacles.

The weapons are nothing special, you have a pistol, small machinegun, big machinegun, assaultrifle, flamethrowers and 2 types of grendes and a rocket launcher.

Whats most annoying is that sometimes you dont know how to proceed. There are endless spawning enemies, do I need to fight or to run? Sometimes you need to kill a certain amout of enemies so something happens, And sometimes you just have to kill the spawner of the enemies to proceed. If you dont do exactly what the game wants from you, you die. Jump over a wall you shouldn`t = kill. Solve a puzzle" otherwise than planned = kill. Thats frustrating and very sad coded.

Before I just list some points that were cool on the game or sh itty I have to say  that I COULDN`T FINISH THE GAME. Because in the last level on an elevator I ALWAYS fall through the map and die. Loaded the map several times and I couldn`t fix the bug. That was the time to uninstall for me. If something serious like this doesn`t get patched you know how much the devs care about their game.

Positive aspects of the game:
+ The music was overall very awesome.
+ The scenery was well done with all the nonstop explosions and the feeling you are really in a war between factions.
+ The other soldiers who mostly follow you give you a feeling that you arent alone in this "war".
+ Funny ideas like
date: you try to open a door but you can`t because suddenly a ghost appears and took away the handle
recommended:
made me smile at least.
+ Story is ok to understand and you know at least what you are fighting for.

- KI incredible stupid and own allies completly useless.
- Enemies are bulletsponges like hell. A centaur and griffons are able to absorb 2 minutes of nonstop gunfire which is just dumb.
- Named allis got too less of personality that you could care about them.
- Jumping is broken and you feel like you can`t even pass a blade of grass.
- TOO much ammo around every corner.
- The superpowers feel really useless. The nonstop absorbing souls to heal the own life is just more annoying than fun.
Medipacks would have done the job I guess. Potential wasted there...
- 9000! Wasnt able to finish the game due to a gamebreaking bug where I always fall through the ground...

Peace Hexor.


"

reviewText: One of the reviewers mentioned that there should be a neutral" button
recommended: beside the thumbs-up and down selections. And how right he was! As I have found Legendary relatively mediocre I would not recommend it
hoursPlayed: but it is not a bad game
voteText:
at all.

Legendary is an interesting FPS. It tries to have a unique story by unleashing mythical creatures on our modern world. Minotaurs and huge werewolves stroll the streets looking for prey. And it's all because of a thief trying to steal an artifact. As there's an order behind all this you can expect to encounter human foes along the hordes of beasts. To make the gameplay a bit more interesting our protagonist has a unique power due to the use of mentioned artifact - this can be used to hurt villains but only after collecting all the energy residue left behind by monsters.

There really is not much to say about Legendary. It is a mediocre game but what it was aimed at it achieves very well. There are some nice scripted sequences and some huge boss battles. Using a rocket launcher against the Kraken in London is very entertaining; at one point you come across with a huge griffin beast in a cathedral. I say some of these monster encounters are coupled with the appropriate environment to make these scenes memorable.

Too bad you complete the story in a mere 5 hours and Legendary is pretty much done for as multiplayer is not played by anyone. I'd say give it a try if you have an awful lot of spare time and a very open-minded approach to these games."

reviewText:
Legendary: The Box is a 5-hour linear Call of Duty style cinematic setpiece FPS. You play as a dude who is hired to open Pandora's Box by an Evil Mad Scientist who runs some sort of Private Mercenary Cult. When you do, monsters come out. The monsters including werewolves, minotaurs, and gryphons. And the Kraken. In the second level, you kill a giant trash golem that wrecks time Square. The Kraken wrecks Big Ben. In the end, you overload Pandora's Box with Cyber Energy or something and then the bad guy dies. The ending sets you up for a sequel where, like, your Cyber Energy lets you control the monsters and as it turns out the good guys were a bad evil government or something all along.

The shooting is not particularly good. Enemies are a bit spongy and don't react to being shot, except Alpha Werewolves, whose skin starts to fall off. Both types of Werewolves need to be decapitated or they will revive themselves, doing so with the axe is pretty fun the first few dozen times. Unfortunately since they're one of the game's main enemies, it gets old. Quickly. AI is pretty weak. Guns: Assault Rifle, Machine Gun, Rocket Launcher, Shotgun, Pistol, end-of-game Flamethrower, axe. You can carry two at once. The boss fights all have unlimited ammo rocket supplies near them. Hmm.

There are no real branching paths, even areas that should be open have debris blocking your way so you're funneled through the linear intended path. You go through sewers. It hits all the clichÃ©s. Occasionally you stop to push a switch or turn a valve or fight waves of enemies until the game decides to let you go on. There are data diaries you can pick up. They have riveting anonymous text like We're going to have to take a run for it the monsters are everywhere". The PC version does not have achievements and there is no in-game incentive to find the diaries. I stopped reading them after a level or two.

The game would have taken me less than 5 hours
date: but the checkpointing is pretty poor so expect to repeat long walking segments when you manage to get yourself killed at the end. I also ran into a 100% guaranteed bug just before the last checkpoint of the game that causes you to fall through the level geometry. To solve it you need to edit an INI to either bind a noclip to some control or to cap the framerate of the game at 30. This did not endear me to the game. It is well documented on Steam discussion forums.\n\nOne of the more positive reviews of the game claims it's 8 hours long. I'm sorry
recommended: it's just not. It just isn't. Again
hoursPlayed: I died a bunch and fell through the game's geometry a bunch at the end and had to restart and fiddle with that and I got to a hair over 5 hours on Normal difficulty. It's not an 8 hour game.\n\nThe game has a hard rock soundtrack and a pretty bad attitude. It's almost a horror FPS except that it's not scary
voteText: it's just... abrasive. Like you're constantly being yelled at
helpfulPercent: I guess. It's very loud. There are sporadic moments that are sort of inventive but mostly they're covered by sort of a very generic game shell.\n\nDid I hate it? Well

reviewText:
Legendary is that odd little game that stirred up so much disappointment and controversy with FPS fans upon it's intial arrival, but nearly a decade later, is actually much better than a lot of what passes as a FPS game anymore. Granted, this title is still barely Triple-A status, but a far cry from the notorious reputation it garnered. Sadly, this title and the even-more maligned Turning Point: Fall of Liberty both made and broke it's developer Spark Unlimited, which after two failed titles sank into oblivion afterward. This was the far better-looking and far better-playing of the two major-publisher offerings it had, and even though this game's publisher (Gamecock) would also be bought then assimilated into the fold of some larger being, at least for a brief moment it showed that independant developers and publishers could still compete in the Triple-A gaming world. But enough about the back-history, onto the game.

Legendary basically tells the tale of opening Pandora's Box, but in a modern setting. The player assumes the role of Charles Deckard, who is cursed with a life-absorbing sigil on his hand after breaking into the museum holding the box and opening it ubeknownst to it's true power. His employer, one Ormond LeFey, wished to unleash the horrors from the box and then wrestle control of them to rule the world with the help of his Black Order. But the Council of 98 (charged with protecting the box throughout history), jumps to Deckard's aid to try and help set things right. Decent and original enough story, just not executed with the most interesting gameplay.

Legendary isn't awful, it isn't even bad, it just has very conventional Doom/Quake style blast 'em FPS gameplay against mythological baddies like werewolves, minotaurs, dragons, gryphons, Cthulu-style tentacle monsters, and even evil faeries. The garden-variety shotguns, assault rifles, SMGs, grenades etc. serve their purpose just fine, but if anything is to be a let down here, it's the Human enemies and their almost listless AI that prove to be the least entertaining of targets in the player's travels. Additionally, this game has areas of infiinte monster respawns, arbitrarily intermixed with areas of finite enemies, so the player never really knows if they should (or can) clear the area, or just muscle through in a bum-rush fashion onto the next objective. Another gripe is the cumbersome fire axe Decard caries around the whole game a la Half-Life 2's Gordon Freeman; that weapon could have easily just been an extra fillable slot for something else.

Graphics were decried as underwhelming, and I agree that on the console ports, the Unreal 3 engine wasn't properly optimized (as with a lot of mid-2000's third-party titles using the then easy-to-license engine), but on PC, turning up everything to it's highest setting makes Legendary more than sufficiently pretty, if not downright gorgeoous at times, and is one of the better titles I've seen NOT made by Epic Games using the engine. Same goes with the aiming: stiff and oddly wonky on consoles, but smooth and perfectly customizable sensitivity even with gamepad on PC. I think most reviewers were playing this on Xbox 360 anyway at the time, so their arguments hold water for that platform. I remember playing this on 360 and it seemed MUCH worse than the PC version that I almost didn't decide to try due to my bad experience with the console version.

Ultimately, this is simple. fantasy-fueled fun that didn't have the right amount of polish or a really hooky multiplayer to reign in enough of the mainstream market, and during a golden era of FPS games where everything was compared to Halo or Call of Duty, that was a massive no-no, in addition to a poorly optimized console port that would end up being the majority of what this game's intended audience played. This should have been more niche, spent a bit more time in the development oven for both the console ports and multiplayer aspects, and maybe Spark Unlimited would be around to this day working on this game's sequels, meaning I would be reviewing the first entry of a franchise instead of a failed attempt to break into the FPS big leagues. For the few bucks this game costs, you could have less fun playing a game on your smartphone, so give it a try.

reviewText: I originally bought a boxed copy of this game on a whim in Jan 2009.  I had never seen it before and it looked different from the usual fare so I decided to give it a try.  I really enjoyed it, despite a few bugs.  It received some really bad press from IGN and Gamespot, which is odd because when they previewed the game's beta they gave it high marks, so I'm guessing Spark Unlimited couldn't pay for a good review the way some of the larger devs can.  I no longer trust review sites.\n\nI'm going to set the record straight.  Legendary is a pretty good title that's been largely overlooked.  Gameplay is familiar in that it's a fairly straight-forward shooter with a few puzzle elements thrown in.  You get everything from a fire axe to anti-aircraft missiles for an arsenal and gun-toting baddies to a 20-story collosus and everything inbetween for enemies.  If you like running and gunning and fighting monsters with the whole world falling down around you, give it a try.  It's only $10.

The set pieces are awe inspiring and gigantic. When that portal opens in the sky, you will probably stand and look at it for a minute and take in how pretty it is.

This game is also kind of clunky and as a shooter, is as generic as it comes. The general narrative is pretty interesting, but they could of done so much more to really pull you in.

While this game is clunky and generic, you will probably enjoy the graphics more than the gameplay.

This game is worth the $0.74 i bought it for.


Oh, but how good it feels to chop the head off a werewolf.

reviewText:
Legendary is interesting game to say the least. You play as Deckard a theif hired to steal Pandora's Box. You then end up unlocking the box and releasing Legendary creatures to cause havoc among the world with the new found power you gained from the box it's up to you to stop what you had set in motion.
The power given to you is the ability to absorb the spirits of fallen creatures and either use it to heal yourself or push enemies out of your face. The enemies themselves are pretty interesting and varied. The Werewolves are certainly a favorite of mine because Werewolves won't stay dead unless decapitated, meaning after knocking one down you have to go and chop it's head off before it gets back up, unless of course you were aiming for the head then with a well placed headshot they won't be getting back up.
The weapons feel a bit weak and one even sounds like a laser gun but that doesn't mean they are weak. there is a decent enough mix of weapons to change up how you play but it doesn't really matter once you find something you like you will most likely stick with it. Also ammo is scattered all over the game so don't worry too much about it however don't just go around soraying down corridors either.
Speaking of corridors this game is VERY linear. it's a straight forward path the entire wa through. Now for me this isn't nessicarilly a bad thing but for others it may be an issue especially for those who enjoy exploring.
TL:DR I enjoyed my experience with Legendary and it may have some things that turn people off I still like it and recommend it especially given it's current price. Side note just wanna go ahead and say it I feel like this game deserves a reebot. With the technology we have today we could improve this game perhaps make it more open don't make Deckard a mute character and tweak the enemies a bit and it would make a great new gen game.

reviewText:
This could have been an amazing game if it had another year worth of all types of work.

Let me just say the concept, idea, and storyline behind this game are very smart, well thought out, and creative.

But the overall gameplay and execution of the game isn't the best. It is lacking, and a bit dull sometimes.

The single player is short, but the ending was something to crave and leads to a possible sequel.

Overall a very good game, if you can get it on a sale, definitely buy it. If you are me, even on hard mode, you can beat the game in about 6-8 hours.

reviewText:
This game feels like it is only half finished. From the storyboards used as cutscenes, to the sticky controls (I use an xbox 360 wired controller and the analogue controls are extremely jerky) this game looks as though it could have been a real gem but constantly falls short.

There are times when your character literally get's stuck on a ramp or a step, because the programmers haven't made the blocks fit properly. The controls regularly let you down as well, such as the jump (which is the worst jump feature I have ever seen, it's practically a hop) which you can press and time to climb over something and yet you simply don't.

The story starts of well, but by the end it is clear that the writyers have no real idea what they are doing and it pretty much goes to hell quickly. The missions have you jumping around the globe in an instant and the storyboard cutscenes do a really poor job of showing you any sort of time passing.

The ending of the game just sort of happens as well. It doesn't really explain (at least very well) what your role is in stopping things, you just have to use your powers to overcharge a computer that is connected to Pandora's Box..... Which personally I find pretty funny considering this is based on a Greek myth and so I would have figured that there would have been a more magical and godly way to close the box, but apparently not.

Finally, the main reason I am leaving a negative review....

I could have lived with everything I have said up until this point and whilst I wouldn't have recommended the game, I wouldn't have complained either. However, right at the end of the game there is an elevator that is simply broken. You stand in the Elevator to go to the final platform, and your character falls straight through and into nothing, seeing the worldspace dissappear into black above you. I looked this up and it is a known issue that has been complained about since what I am assuming is release (2012). There are posts that claim there are ways to fix it, but none of these fixes worked for me. Frankly though, I shouldn't have to fix a game that has been out for at least 4 years anyway. This is a gamebreaking bug and the developer has quite literally ignored it and ignored the complaints that it has triggered. This is unacceptable and frankly it is disgusting. The only way I could complete the game was by using a noclipping (walk through walls) hack that someone on the forums suggested. This led me to wander through the world space until I found the next trigger point to be able to continue the mission. Again, this is pathetic and unacceptable.

Do not buy this game. Whether it is Â£10 or 1p, I would not recommend paying for a game that is riddled with bugs and where the developer clearly doesn't care. Save your money and buy something from a studio that cares about the product that they release.

reviewText:
A decent cinematic FPS compareable to Half-Life, Bioshock or Metro from its gameplay, pacing and progression making you traverse post-apocalyptic-ish levels by rather indirect means and engaging various types of enemies inbetween.

A wealthy/evil entrepreneur leading a secret society tricked you, a silent mercenary, into opening Pandora's Box in modern New York. Mythological creatures assault the world and you traverse broken - most of the time urban - areas in an effort to halt/reverse the spread utilizing the help of another secret society, man-made firepower and a signet that was burned into the back of your hand when you opened the box and that allows you to absorb energy - Animus Vitae" - from dead creatures restoring your health as well as stagger them briefly with a burst of it.

The story is rather basic stuff of evil guy dooming the world and you going to save the day. Well
recommended: as the ending isn't as definitive - the devs clearly left room for a sequel which I would like to see as there is sort of a cliffhanger making me a little hungry for more
hoursPlayed: but I'm not sure if this will ever happen for this seems like an under-the-radar title. The gamebreaking bug towards the end that the devs obviously never got around to fix seems to be a proof of that (there is one workaround or another for this bug
voteText: but its still a severe one).\n\nAiming is rather hard for reasons unknown to me. I haven't fiddled around with the options much but I've read other reviewers had similar issues. It's rather imprecise and twitchy. Putting the crosshair on a certain small spot is almost impossible. It's similar to what I experienced in Bioshock. It's doable when shooting from the hip but aiming down the sights or going for specific hit zones (like the heads) can be a pain. Some reviewers argued this adds to the challenge
helpfulPercent:
and while this is true at first glance it's very artifical nonetheless (I could also blindfold one of my eyes or tie one of my hands to my back to increase the challenge).

Sometimes I would have hoped for more checkpoints. One boss fight or another and some puzzle-ish scenes with me interacting with various environmental things to open blocked paths while certain enemies "stalking" me took me longer than I had expected. It felt a little tedious at times. When I took more care and understood how things worked I got them done though.

The characters could have deserved a bit more love. Besides you
votesHelpful: the silent mercenary
votesTotal: and the evil businessman there is a somewhat self-confident and sexy-ish female companion (who may remind the player of Alyx Vance - but then she too was an archetype character)
votesFunny: some high-ranking military guy advising/ordering you around and nameless field-operatives you wouldn't want to get to know better as they like to get eaten by the creatures. The characters are not bad for what they are supposed to be - they serve their roles and their voice actors are good - but they aren't surprising or too memorable either.\n\nStill
commentsCount: despite it's flaws and that one bug it's game that plays out fairly well and consistent from start to end. It holds a decent premise of throwing mythological creatures at the world and the player
column16: providing some nice settings (New York Times Square for example) and being pretty good at creating the ambiance that the world is getting torn apart by those creatures
column18: werewolves and other creatures lurking about and stalking the close or distant skies
column20: the waters and just about anything else. The fight between the two secret societies with you in the middle of it felt quite believable too. The game takes some effort into teaching mythology by providing brief intel about the creatures you encounter (and how the two societies are related to the whole affair) and putting you into the need to adapt a little when fighting them because their nature gives them certain strengths and weaknesses. There are pickable data logs scattered around the levels too that flesh out their background a little
column21: either informing you about the activities of hostile or allied agents on the field or about former citizens and how they experienced the attacks from the creatures.\n\nHad this game gotten more polish and maybe more advertising perhaps it could have been brought to a similar level as Half-Life
column23: Metro or other games of this kind. It's not too far away from that either
column25: and in this manner I believe this is an underrated game."

reviewText:
Steam needs a neutral setting, or a slider or something, because Legendary is a strange one. I got it on the cheap long ago, and it's an interesting concept, if nothing else.

The game revolves around you, Deckard, who causes the world to be devastated with monsters of forgotten mythology. At the same time, you have parties for and against you, trying to stop you because apparently, they like these monsters to destroy the world, and to help you because the perils of survival rest in your hands. Convenient because you hold the power of Pandora's Box, able to kill or heal with the arcane energy that you recharge by killing your foes and absorbing said energy.

I use these fancy words, but the game is just an FPS for the fairness of it. It runs in Unreal Engine 3, making it semi-pretty, but very meh in visuals. The level design isn't exactly impressive, the world around you is crumbled worse than a Call of Duty setpiece. It's all so standard, the only thing driving it is the mythical creatures that attack and your abilities.

The game info states that it's a singleplayer game, but it DOES have online multiplayer and support for a 360 controller, although you would be hard-pressed not to use the KB and mouse, since this is a PC title. Obviously, the game's age and lackluster quality means there's basically no community for this game, though.

At the time of review, this game is on sale for 3 quarters. Less than a dollar, a couple of trading cards will get you this game.
$0.74. For the price, I'd say you'll get more than your money's worth out of it. For the $5 price it would usually hold, I would not recommend it.

reviewText: In a gaming industry with increasing repetition, it's nice to see a game take a chance with something different, and I think it pays off in Legendary. The mix of enemies is nice, as well as the feeling of being caught in a three-sided conflict. Each of the monster enemies has different strategies, creating some tactical variety. The environments, though not particularly original, suit the gameplay quite nicely (although frequently feeling cramped, there aren't enough big open areas that make for the best fights in the game). Unfortunately, Legendary does feel somewhat lacking in content; there are few weapons, and there's little reason to use anything other than the newest weapons you've found (and only one melee weapon available). While the enemies are varied, there's only a few types; more monsters to fight and more variety amongst enemy soldiers would be welcome. The game is also fairly short, and can be beaten in an afternoon without much trouble (which suits the limited enemy types). Animus powers (the games spells, for lack of a better term) also seem underutilized. Walking away from Legendary, it almost feels like a teaser for a better game that, sadly, won't be coming.\n\nOverall, I recommend Legendary for an afternoon of fun; it's enjoyable and different, but it won't blow anyone away.

reviewText:
... Where do I begin?

The mechanics of this game are decently passable, even perhaps entertaining. The enemy layout and enemies, feel like a slog. Padding and unfair juking, that are eventually easy to put down if you WAIT FOR IT. This game tries to be all action and fast-paced â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, then throws in things you can't avoid being hit by, things that go incorporeal, things that you need energy to even hit when energy is scarce, and other 'fun' issues. Oh, and the last level is broken so you have to fiddle with config settings to bypass it. Then... Just when the game seems to be getting good, Right when you're about to have a 'Sorry kid, name's Frank Fontaine' moment, slideshow featuring the coolest damn thing they didn't put in the game, the incredibe setup for a fight that actually grows some sense of attachment for the player now that he knows the character, and roll credits?! Oh, and, uh... Yeah. You play someone that can suck the life force out of things. Functionally vampire vs werewolves... I'm not directly screaming twilight, but...

Get out. BEGONE from my library of installed titles and never return. I condemn thee to my 'Crap' folder!

reviewText:
Traditional Rating - 5.5/10
Recommendation - Play Singularity instead.

This game kind of slides into the same slot as Singularity: Slightly-older, somewhat-obscure, non-AAA shooter. Unfortunately, where Singularity shines, this game falls flat. Where Singularity's story is interesting, this one is bland. Where Singularity's gunplay and enemies are interesting, Legendary's are frustrating. The only exception is the BEASTLY fire-axe, which I rather enjoyed.

-The graphics in this game are passable. They fit their purpose, but show their age.
-The sounds are actually quite good. The burst-fire rifle in particular I enjoyed.
-The voice acting is on the low side of B-movie quality. C+ movie, maybe.
-The enemies, for the most part, are quite frustrating. The one enemy I did enjoy is the little rolling brimstone demons. Their AI was fun.

Overall, the game is a disappointment. On the high-side, it's generic. On the low-side, it's teeth-gratingly frustrating. For example, let me explain the moment where I gave up on the game:

There is a gigantic golem thrashing around the city streets (who for some reason attacks everyone else, but never tries to attack me), and I'm running around charging up EMP generators. Working on the 3rd one, I ran into a building filled with little pixie enemies that can only be hit when they feel like it (they turn ethereal" and seem to only turn solid when your back is turned)
date: and some little will-o-wisp thing immediately possesses the EMP generator and moves it up a floor. After getting slashed in the back by a dozen more of the stupid little pixies

Not one single part of that whole encounter were challenging. The entire thing was just pecking at me. The dumb little pixies posed no threat

reviewText:
While at times the concept is taken to a neat place it also suffers from unimaginative set pieces that drag down much of the style. Sometimes the game can host fun firefights while most of the time the level design is linear in a claustrophobic and tedious way.

It also suffers from awkward sub-mechanics as well, especially regarding its enemy types.  For instance
you have werewolves that you can permanently kill through unusual means, only to face them in situations where they infinitely respawn which ultimately negates the point of killing them off permanently.  Awkward design decisions are plentiful throughout the experience.  Also why would they design jumping puzzles when the player can only jump upwards or two to three feet max?

But thats not to say that the game is entirely without fun, there are a couple of neat firefights here and there.  For the most part though it is an jaunt through tedious levels with design that will bore and frustrate the player.  So while there is fun to be had ultimately the majority of the experience is not worth playing.

reviewText:
Legendary
More like Legendarily bad.

This game is about as linear and dull as you can get, the game has some interesting ideas when it comes to health mechanics but they fail to make anything unique of it and just turn it into a poorly done medkit system.

The enemies are dull and uninteresting, the set piece moments are all done in gameplay but they're so far away from you that you never get the sense of scale that makes them interesting and you're always safe from their massive destruction that everyone screams about in-game, so it feels more like you're on an amusement park ride than actually being a participant in the world.

The guns are also just uninteresting and the game has horrid mouse acceleration and just made me want to vomit.
For some reason you can also jump but I don't know why, you only go about 5cm off the ground and at no point can you ever really jump over anything, you're railroaded into a set path sooo much.

Legendarily awful.
Legendarily sickening.
Legendarily BOOOORRRIIINNNG.
Legendarily uninteresting story and characters(using the term characters loosely since they have no character at all)
LEGENDARILY DULL.

DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY.
I bought it for $2.50, played it to completion, and I feel like a victim of highway robbery.

reviewText:
I bought this game already knowing it is a bad game, but it was under Â£1 and I figured 'how bad could it really be?'. Well, the answer to that is 'really, really bad'.

So what makes it so bad? I'll exlain:

Bland visuals with low quality textures
Limited weapon variety
Limited enemy variety
Horrible fps cap
Bugs
More bugs
Game-breaking bugs
Massively bullet-spongey enemies
Janky controls
Extremely limited configuration options
Volume issues in cut-scenes
Very linear
Terrible voice acting
Abysmal animations

So are there good things about the game? Well, it is, mercifully, quite short so you only need to waste a single afternoon/evening playing it. That's a good thing, I guess. Anything else? Nope. The game itself has almost no redeeming features whatsoever.

Do not buy this game, no matter how cheap it is. It's not the waste of money that's the issue; it's the waste of time that could be better spent playing a game that isn't so awful.

reviewText: It's playable, I guess.  But overall, it's incredibly mediocre.  The enemy AI is either sit behind waist high cover and shoot at you, or charge you. Werewolves  have a stupid gimmick of only dying permanently if you decapitate them.  There are fire lizards that you can only stem the flow of by activating the water pipe that is always above them.  Griffons appear like twice as fightable enemies, and only one is actually difficult to fight at all.  It works as a game, but is incredibly boring and mediocre.\n\nAnd I swear that this game only has two tracks of music.

reviewText:
An FPS released in 2008 and seems dated even for then.

You're a thief hired to open Pandora's Box. Apparently, you've never heard of it before...

Anyway, as expected all hell breaks loose. Mythical monsters roam the planet destroying mankind. (Weak werewolves, regular were wolves, griffons, golems, fire things, mintoaurs, and some bug things.) Now you have to find a way to reseal the box.

Game play is very meh. There are oddly long stretches between fights throughout the game. Your weapon choices are very limited and as pointed out earlier, there isn't a large variety in enemies. Also, I've gone through every possible thing you can do in the game yet Steam shows me as having only played 12 hours.

The bad part of that is it includes all the time I had it paused and at least an hour of troubleshooting.

Why was I troubleshooting? Because there is a game killing bug right at the end of the game that the developer never cared about fixing. Getting around it requires some forum searches, some file editing, and possibly installing FRAPS (that fixed it for me).

So yeah, there's a bug at the end that many people hit, and was never fixed, that literally stopped your progress cold. For me, that's unforgivable, even if the rest of the game wasn't blah.

I'd say my feelings aren't unique because they set this game up for a sequel and you'll notice there isn't one.

Skip it.

reviewText:
There's a clear issue with stupidly hard parts on normal. I genuinely recommend play it on easy. The bigger creatures are very hard to beat on normal difficutly, and you end up swearing at it. It constantly goes from easier bit to incredibly hard bit. Shooting is inconsistent, meaning sometimes enemies go straight down, and others take all eight rounds of the shotgun.

It has a lot of, 'where do I go now' and 'how do I do this', moments.

Weapons only feel medoicre-average maybe, and they swap positions in your mouse scroll. That means you struggle to find the weapon you want in time. Literally sometimes the axe is bound to key 1, then key 3. Your other two weapons keep changing slot.

There's another really nasty insult which is the radio voice chatter. It is infuriatingly squelchy and screechy. In headphones it's pure pain. I do not know how anyone had the audacity to create and put that in a game.

Overall it's an average-poor old type shooter. Shame because the idea is average-good. I decided to buy it because I saw werewolves and guns on the Steam store page screenshots. In the sale I bought it for Â£0.39, so I lost nothing because I easily go the fun back. I have played five hours and am tired of it. I might finish it though, but can't say right now; 50/50. I can't recommend it, and I can understand its poor reviews. However if you play on easy and give a it a once through, I can see genuine fun in it.

Yes, yes, I know this game was gifted to me and I didn't spend any money on it but I would happily give this game back for a full refund of 0 pence. reviewText:
I don't understand why this game has so much negative criticism. I decided to play this seeing that it was only around Â£1.80, I liked the Idea of the game. The gameplay is relatively straight-forward: Do this, kill this, find your way around or out of this, etc. However, the game's plot is what makes it so good.

--SPOILER ALERT!--

The story places you in the boots of a man who is persuaded into opening Pandora's box, he inadvertedly sets the world into a cataclysm as mythological creatures begin to invade the world, the myths and the humans are caught in a war. However it only appears that the myths aren't the major threat. early on you find out about the man who hired you -LeFay- is attempting to control the creatures for himself and you are brought into a group known as the Council of 98 who are attempting to stop LeFay's army's -The Black Order- plans. Both the council of 98 and the black order are caught in a war against each other and the myths.


-My opinion-

This game is very good, and I believe that the game is worth playing, as it is extremely well developed and the gameplay is well executed.

reviewText:
Ich kann nicht verstehen wie man bei dem Spiel Wirklich abraten kann... Zudem wenn ich einige der Negativen Rewiews lese glaube ich die Leute haben temporÃ¤ren GedÃ¤chtnisverlust...

Zusammenfassung:
Ja es ist kein Weltklasse-Shooter, aber bei einem Preis von 5 Euro ist das Spiel voll in Ordnung und hat viele gute Aspekte.

Kurz was zur Story:
Eine Story um Pandoras Box, Okay ein alter Hut Aber an sich ganz gut umgesetzt. Hier und da LogiklÃ¼cken, aber fÃ¼r einen Shooter eine gute Story und gut in Szene gesetzt. Das Ende hat mich Ã¼brigens echt bedauern lassen dass es keinen 2. teil gibt, der wÃ¤re bestimmt nochmal besser als das hier.

Das schlechte:
Nun Zuerst muss man da wohl das Gunplay nennen. Es ist nicht kaputt, aber schwammig und im Zielmodus hat selbst die LMG kaum RÃ¼ckstoÃŸ. Zudem stÃ¶rt das gerade im Schleichen extreme Headbobbing hier schon..
Dann noch die andauernden Zwangsbremsen... Hier mal eine Schalttafel Ã¼berbrÃ¼ckt, hier ein Ventiel gedreht, Da was beiseite geschoben, Ehrlich gesagt, ich verstehe es nicht. Immer wieder muss man eine TÃ¼r durch eine Ã¼bern Daumen ca 10sekÃ¼ndige Aktion Ã¶ffnen. In den meisten FÃ¤llen passiert wÃ¤hrenddessen gar nichts. (Ab und an kommt da was aber nur eine Hand voll im Spiel) Deas hÃ¤lt den Spielfluss auf stÃ¶rt aber im Endeffekt nur teils.
Die KI der Menschlichen Gegner... Wir Schiebens mal auf: 'Der Fokus liegt auf den Monstern' Aber die Menschlichen Gegner sind dumm wie Brot und treffen teils schlechter als jeder Stormtrooper, Der BÃ¶sewicht hat wohl keine besonders hohen Einstellungsvoraussetzungen.
Das 'an die Hand nehmen'... Es ist sooo bescheuert. Du brauchst nicht denken, alles was wichtig ist ist leuchtend hervorgehoben...

Das Neutrale:
Die Grafik ist mittelmaÃŸ, fÃ¼r seine Zeit und die UE3 nicht ganz zeitgemÃ¤ÃŸ, aber es sieht Stellenweise echt gut aus, und an anderen Stellen wieder wie hinge... naja. Es ist ansehnlich, wenn man stellenweise wegguckt.
Die KI der Monster, sie ist in Ordnung, aber stellenweise auch sehr vorhersehbar.
Das Leveldesign, teils ist es ein Korridor of Duty, teils bietet es schÃ¶ne offene Areale mit freiem vorgehen. Nichts besonders gutes, aber die Abwechslung empfinde ich positiv.

Das gute:
Die Monster. Es ist wirklich toll man hat hier 4 Permanente Gegnertypen, die man jeweils anders bekÃ¤mpfen muss. Eine gute Abwechslung, die SpaÃŸ in den Kampf bringt und teilweise SchlachtflÃ¤chen, die ein wenig nachdenken erfordern. HÃ¤tte ich gerne mehr von.
Die BosskÃ¤mpfe sind extrem gut in Szene gesetzt ohne das Spielgeschehen zu unterbrechen, hierbei auch eine echt gute Umsetzung des Gegnerdesigns.
Das Anima-System. Du kannst die Seelen der monster sdammeln und dich damit heilen(Und ein paar andere Dinge machen) Ein echt schÃ¶nes System und eine gut umgesetzte Idee.
Die Waffenauswahl ist in Ordnung und so gesehen ist jede Waffe hier gut einsetzbar. Trotz allem der Flammenwerfer ist zu stark.

Bemerkungen am Rande:
Der oft genannte Fahrstulbug ist bei mir nicht aufgetreten (Stand 7.5.15) Wird also weg sein.
Der Multiplayer ist faktisch nicht mehr existent (Gamespy) LAN Ginge noch, aber ist halt LAN.
Es gibt keinen Grund das Spiel auf Steam zu kaufen solange es nicht im Angebot ist. Wenn ihr wie ich Steam mÃ¶gt ist Okay, aber es ist hierbei wirklich gleich wenn man sich eine DRM-Freie Version holt.

reviewText:
You'd think a first person shooter about shooting griffons and werewolves in a apocalyptic world would be LEGENDARY right? Where unleashing a horde of nasty mythical creatures into the world to wreak havoc giving you the satisfaction of hunting down grand beasts would be great right? Well I'll tell you right now that It's not a great game but is it as bad as everybody says? To be honest, with you - no, it's actually a pretty enjoyable game. Not amazing but fun. The campaign will take up to about 6-8 hours to beat so it's not too long but long enough to where you can have a good amount of fun with the game. 6-8 whole hours of nasties that just shot out of Pandora's Box (How a tiny thing could fit so many griffons in is completely beyond me but it's pretty cool) and I want to talk quickly about these nasties because Pandora's Box is meant to based on Greek Mythology right? Well funny enough there is probably only one creature in the game that's based solely on Greek Mythology, and that's the Minotaur. You'd think there would be things like skeletons, cyclopses, harpies, manticores, gorgons and what-not right? Well no, most of the monsters are based on folklore from other places around the world which is cool but still that irks me just a little bit as unnecessary as that sounds but a little bit of mythical consistency would have been nice but then again the story is definitely not the game's strong point. It's a nitpick so I just let it slide.

Well with all the bullocks out the way let's begin the part of the review that actually matters:
Pros:
- Fun and satisfying gunplay (Yes, you can hip fire just fine which is always a bonus)
- Beautiful art direction
- Interesting array of enemies based on myths and folklore around the world
- Monster AI is quite intriguing and will use the environment best to their advantage (Throw objects, climb across walls, etc)
- Animus abilities are cool, but you need to strategize on how you use it (Unless there is anima everywhere)
- No lazy regenerating health, healing is done by collecting anima, basically the blood of your fallen enemies are your source of health
- The game's Serious Sam Netricsa-styled PDA does provide some fairly interesting lore on the creatures and backstory
- Controller support which is always nice for those who prefer controller
- Â£4 (Or your regional equivalent) is a fair price but I do suggest getting whenever it's on sale

Cons:
- Graphics are very sub-par despite the art direction
- Enemy human AI are stupid and can be really cheap at times
- Not many weapons to play around with
- The campaign is a little too linear
- I would have liked the campaign to be a bit longer
- The multiplayer is dead, no you can't go alone and treat it as a horde mode - you need one player on either side which is always a terrible decision when there is an NPC team
- No bots, for â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥'s sake developers if you want your multiplayer to survive at least put it some â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing bots you lazy â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥s - I will criticize any game that does this with their multiplayer
- Story and characters are paper thin
- Voice acting is hilariously bad at points
- Animations for the people are dodgy (They're mostly fine with the monsters)
- I think the monsters could have better designs, I mean the minotaur looks like a giant baby slamming his rattle all over the place
- Boss fights are naff
- Despite the nice little twist, it has a very rushed and terrible ending
- Odd and bumpy geometry, don't know what's going on with that
- The elevator before the final battle is bugged to all hell as it throws you out of the map and kills you, so you cannot progress unless you lock the game to 30FPS (Here's the fix for that; Open the PandoraEngine.ini (it is on C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\My Games\Legendary\PandoraGame\Config-Folder) and search for
MaxSmoothedFrameRate=300" then change the 300 to 30) Credit goes to PawPaw on the Steam Forums

Overall
date: I would recommend this game. It's flawed
recommended: VERY flawed but it's a fun and very charming game in it's own right with beautiful art direction
hoursPlayed: fun gameplay and an interesting array of enemies to fight. I want to see this concept done so much more in games
voteText: fighting mythical beasts is actually very satisfying - gunning down werewolves with an LMG? Why not! Shooting Griffons out of the sky with a rocket launcher? Oh yeah! Scorching minotaurs with a flamethrower? Sounds like fun! We've had enough zombie games
helpfulPercent: we've had enough alien shooters and we've faced terrorists countless sodding times - I think there's enough room to give this concept another bash because it's a fantastic idea even if it's poorly executed here. I want to see more games that take on the whole mythical FPS subject.\n\nI have heard that the multiplayer
votesHelpful: despite being dead is actually quite fantastic - it's a mix of a competitive objective-based game mode similar to capture the flag combined with a horde mode as the third NPC team decimates players on both ends but also constitute towards the goal of the main game mode. I am genuinely interested in seeing what this game mode is
votesTotal: I think I'll try it out with someone and see how it goes.\n\nBut yep
votesFunny: my conclusion is it's a fun yet flawed game. Just know that it will have problems going in but if you can stomach the annoyances then you will find a decently fun and charming FPS with a unique twist to it."

reviewText:
http://kotaku.com/5684349/the-evolution-of-the-first-person-shooter
If you like the look of 2010 fps level design, consider this review a thumbs up.

Maybe the game becomes more interesting later on, but I just couldn't bring myself to play any more.  It feels like watching a movie on a broken VHS where you have to press the play button every 30 seconds to continue playing.  In my short time with the game, I never felt like I was in control but rather pressing that button to get to the next cutscene.

In a more positive light, I didn't encounter any bugs and the game played smoothly on my machine.

reviewText:
For a game that came out in 2008, during a time when it had a lot to compete with in the shooter genre, Legendary was suprsingly good! There wasn't much to do with games then as AI was limited and graphics were too but the devs definately made a playable combination of diffculty and entertainment. If you like mythology and big, violent creatures tearing people apart, this game is for you. If you get bored VERY EASILY with linear gameplay, this game is not for you. It was 2008 when this came out, remember, there weren't a whole bunch of open ended games then.
If I could fix two things, I would have asked for more weapons/animus abilites and better collision detection.
There are times where you're running in a straight line to escape an enemy and you suddenly stop - not because you meant to but because your character got stuck on a penny-sized bump on the sidewalk or a plant. Seriously.
Other than those two minor hiccups, the game was great for what it was and when it was made. Over all, 8/10. 2 points off for aforementioned problems/issues.

reviewText:
While the action in this game is decent, it does so many things wrong I can't recommend it.

If you play this you will enjoy it to an extent, then you will have the game dump on you for no reason.

reviewText:
Paid $50 on launch. Completely Disapointed.
The game is unpolished in every sense of the word, Weapons feel powerless, Sound design is the exact same Loud echo pop gunshots that COD: WAW and the dev's previous game Turning Point: Fall of Liberty use. Animations are somewhat bearable, but below the standard for late 2008 even.  Scripted events often fail to impress, or assume the player is in a location he might not be in. It was kinda fun-ish. Not Half-life 2 fun. Not even playing tennis or a sport outside fun. But it was fun to overcome the game's challenges which were mostly based on poor design and not actual challenge.

Which brings me to the reccomendation.

For 74 cents or even $4.99 It's worth it to try it out. You might kinda sorta have fun. Having paid $50 I forced myself to wade through the terrible emotionless main character, the tedious scripted events, all of it. And It wasn't worth $50 at all. But If it was launched as a budget title for only 19.99 on launch, then dropped to 15, 10, then 5, it would have been far more forgivable. They realized this and it's 1/10th the price when it's not on sale. or typically 3/4th of a dollar when on sale. That is amazing. Spark Unlimited won me back with Lost Planet 3, and even though Legendary isn't nearly a good game, it's worth your chance for three quarters.

reviewText: It got some bad press but it's still a hell of a ride. It feels more like you're in Cloverfield than anything, constantly navigating through crowded cityscapes while they're being destroyed from giant monsters. The game's poorly viewed because it's on more rails than a Disneyland ride, but I realized that this was the best way to see this game: as not much of one. Instead, enjoy the chaos around you as you hold down the W key and look around with your mouse. There are smaller enemies to fight, but nothing taxing. The 3D's showing it's age, so even on maxed out settings the poly modeling and animations just aren't that great. But Legendary makes up for these deficiencies in sheer spectacle...and a $2.50 price tag when I took the plunge.

reviewText: Legendary, in concept, could have been a very compelling experience. Myths and legends released from Pandora's box by an unsuspecting thief who then must fight hordes of monsters, not to make everything right, but for survival. reviewText:
This game is not as bad as everyone claims it to be, the story is quite good and some areas have some really memorable parts, if you love Mythic or Legendary Creatures this is a must to get, you get to kill Werewolves, Fairies, Minotaurs and other creatures.

It has just one horrible horrible unforgivable mistake, there is this glitch when getting to the ending of the game where you get into an Elevator and you keep falling CONSTANTLY through the Elevator floor into your death, there is no way to avoid this unless you get into the game ini settings and set the game to 30 FPS max, anything higher and you will keep falling through the floor, another horrible mistake is the unskipable cinematics.

Overall is not as bad as everyone claim, seriously the game is good but is rather short.

My score for this game is 7.2 out of 10.

reviewText:
The game looks nice and enjoyable to a certain degree, however it is so scripted that you can't do anything unless the game says so. The most obvious examples are at the start of the game when you are attacked by gryphons, but you can't damage them in anyway, even when your axe goes straight through them. Slightly later you meet your first werewolf that will attack you twice, but won't do any damage to you (you also cannot attack it).
While you solve some of the puzzles the game will just keep on spawning enemies every X seconds until you solve it.

The first point irritates me enough to just quit the game out right. If you can however carry through you MIGHT find a fun game.

reviewText:
Legendary is one of those FPSes that had an interesting premise: i.e. fight legendary creatures (griffons and more), but ultimately came away as a Half-life clone, where you go through the world exactly as the developers intended, watch somethings happen in the gameworld (many instances of tentacles of creatures dragging off / killing NPCs) and you can't interfere. While it was fresh and we saw scientist got pulled through ceiling hole and then gibblets came back out. it's no longer so interesting a decade later.

Furthermore, the game basically postulated that not only the legends were all real (all the myth like werewolf, tentacles, and much more were real, there are also hidden forces, very well equipped (equipvalent to modern military), that just suddenly get into the city instead of the real military. Ancient secret societies that stayed together forever, and evil mastermind and all that. It's a lot like Underworld, except it wasn't a war between Vampires and Lycans, but merely, Black Hand (evil) and Council of 98 (good), humans vs. humans.

Mechanically the game is a normal FPS, albeit with a bit of extra thing about this animus". If you defeat one of these special critters
date: you get to collect their life force
recommended: the animus. It can be used to heal yourself
hoursPlayed: or to power actual devices (why? Don't they have batteries or generators?)  And I'm only a little in. And there are certainly a lot of these creatures.  You can also use the energy to do a "stun bolt". As some of the enemies are infinite respawns
voteText: you shold not run out of energy\n\nThe game is also dotted with "environmental puzzles"
helpfulPercent: most of which are rather simple
votesHelpful: and one of the earliest stumpers simply didn't give enough hint. At other times
votesTotal: the "break the 4th wall" hint totally broke the mood. For example
votesFunny: how do you kill a werewolf? You "kill" it
commentsCount: then cut off its head\n\nAll in all
column16: Legendary is a relic of the FPS era
column19: there was little of any fight against the critters"

reviewText:
I know this game is from 2008, so it's going to seem like I'm picking on it a little bit.
Aesthetically, it's a game with big, although not pretty skyboxes. The game is so unashamed to use invisible walls that it becomes massively obvious where the level designer wanted you to go. Gameplay wise, it's your standard First person shooter, with lots of knee high walls, your default squishy human, hard wearing mythical creatures and tank-like minotaurs, but most enemies except for the minotaurs could be taken down in a few well placed shots. The story concept had mileage to go, but somehow this game really didn't do it justice, either they've had to cut the campaign and story down for financial reasons, or from publisher deadlines, but if I'm honest, I don't care. The ending left me feeling like it'd just cut the wettest of farts and left. It has so many bad story cliches, that if it had any more, I'd have thought I were in a printing mill.

As for the voice acting, I don't know whether they used someone's fake english accent, or they just found some seriously stuck-up lady, but the accent sounded so unbelievably indignant throughout the game, even when you had to save her, not to mention the drawn-out exposition. Hey, I get it lady, I need to go to these three doohickeys and blow them up to shut down the watchamacakllit before time rund out and it goes off... What's that lady, oh, you want to explain it for the extra special soldiers in the room? Sure, it's not like the world is ending and we're on the clock.

It still has potential for a sequel or DLC levels if they had left out that deus ex machina ending, but sadly, what has been done can not be undone.

reviewText: I played this game for a bit, I really tried to like it. It has a lot going for it, a fun story (if cliche), pretty great graphics for an indie  dev, and some decent sound design. However, it is so, so painfully linear. You'll be walking through a large area, say a city, apartment complex, sewer, etc., and there is only one path. So every door is closed or blocked off except for the ONE you have to find. The enemies are pretty cool but very monotonous. You'll go through a very redundant, linear path, blasting the same baddie over and over again. As others mention, it's real buggy. It's one of those that have a lot of potential, could be a really fun corny B-grade game, but it just falls short.

reviewText:
28 minutes.

28 minutes is all it took for me to formulate my opinion about Legendary. Will this game change your life? Yes. Will you always remember playing this game? Yes. Is that a good thing? No.

Legendary is a terrible video-game. I'm glad it was only 75 cents when I bought it. I feel sorry for all the cats who dropped full price on this steaming pile of horse turds. I'll always remember this videogame, and I'll always remember how bad it was. There's a cool thing here with Pandora's Box, and monsters like gryphons and werewolves but it's just not fun, it looks terrible, and it's overall performance is shoddy at best.

Avoid this game like the plague.
